completions: Jean Dujardin gets Connery's mannerisms down pat: the adjusting the cuff links when entering a club as all the women turn to admire him, the unflappable confidence, the seductive voice (in French), and the quiet deadpan expression. Some of the background details of this story are based, very, very loosely, on real events of the era in which this was placed. The story combines elements of fiction and fantasy with reality.
The operational details from the D-Day invasion are very real.

A teen-aged girl gets the horse of her dreams and is trained by an ex-Jockey to participate in London's Grand National Steeplechase. In the course of her training, the girl meets a charming aristocrat who offers to fix the race for an entry fee. She is then faced with having to go against him in the steeplechase at the risk of betraying her trusted trainer.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The movie is divided into two parts: the beginning of Miyazawa Kenji's life, which explains his creed of Life lived, and the second part is made up of the various stories from Miyazawa Kenji's book, Love's Charity, with White Oleander tacked on as the epilogue.<|end_of_text|>

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The townspeople form a posse to destroy the animal, and things seem to be just fine. Well, until they sell off one and realize there's one cat too many, and the creature was actually Katharine Ross, but you can see that part coming, unless you're dumb. Or visually impaired.
